question: Question_01_(c)
sols:
Use logarithmic differentiation on this function.

\begin{align*}
f(x) &=(x+1)^{\cos(x)}\\
\ln(f(x)) &= \ln((x+1)^{\cos(x)})\\
&= \cos(x)\ln(x + 1)\end{align*} Taking the derivative of this equation with respect to $x$
gives:

\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dx}\left[\ln(f(x))\right] &= \frac{d}{dx}\left[\cos(x)\ln(x + 1)\right] \\
\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \\
f'(x) &= f(x)\left( \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \right)\\
{\color{blue}f'(x)} &{\color{blue}\,= (x+1)^{\cos(x)}\left( \frac{\cos(x)}{x + 1} - \sin(x)\ln(x+1) \right)}\end{align*}
hints:
Notice that both the base and exponent of $f(x)$ are functions of $x$,
so neither the power rule nor the exponential derivative rule will work
here. What operation can you do to $f(x)$ to express it as a product of
functions?
Start by taking the logarithm of $f$.
